bill.constitutionalAuthorityStatementText: [Congressional Record Volume 167, Number 85 (Monday, May 17, 2021)][House]From the Congressional Record Online through the Government Publishing Office [www.gpo.gov]By Mr. McHENRY:H.R. 3281.Congress has the power to enact this legislation pursuantto the following:Article I, Section 8, Clause 3: ``To regulate Commerce withforeign nations, and among the several states, and with theIndian Tribes.'' Because the federal government has extendedArticle I, Section 8, Clause 3 beyond its intendedboundaries, it follows that efforts to rein in excessivefederal government encroachment in this area can be justifiedby Article I, Section 8, Clause 3.[Page H2421]

item.name: Environment, Manufacturing, and Critical Materials Subcommittee
Environment, Manufacturing, and Critical Materials Subcommittee

item.text: Referred to the Subcommittee on Environment and Climate Change.
Referred to the House Committee on Energy and Commerce.

item.fullName: Rep. Rosendale Sr., Matthew M. [R-MT-At Large]

summary.text:
Recognizing the Protection of Motorsports Act of 2019 or the RPM Act of 2019 [sic]

This bill authorizes the modification of a vehicle's air emission controls for vehicles that are not legal for operation on a street or highway and are used solely for competition.

bill.title: RPM Act of 2019

item.title: To amend the Clean Air Act to provide an exemption from certain antitampering provisions for certain actions for modifying a motor vehicle that is not legal for operation on a street or highway and is to be used solely for competition, and for other purposes.
Recognizing the Protection of Motorsports Act of 2019

latestAction.text: Referred to the Subcommittee on Environment and Climate Change.

dublinCore.dc:rights: Pursuant to Title 17 Section 105 of the United States Code, this file is not subject to copyright protection and is in the public domain.
dublinCore.dc:contributor: Congressional Research Service, Library of Congress
dublinCore.dc:description: This file contains bill summaries and statuses for federal legislation. A bill summary describes the most significant provisions of a piece of legislation and details the effects the legislative text may have on current law and federal programs. Bill summaries are authored by the Congressional Research Service (CRS) of the Library of Congress. As stated in Public Law 91-510 (2 USC 166 (d)(6)), one of the duties of CRS is "to prepare summaries and digests of bills and resolutions of a public general nature introduced in the Senate or House of Representatives". For more information, refer to the User Guide that accompanies this file.
